newsitem.title: JAPAN: TSE pinpoints cause of electronic failure.
newsitem.headline: TSE pinpoints cause of electronic failure.

text.p: The Tokyo Stock Exchange (TSE) said on Monday it had traced a technical failure that affected trading on Friday to a loop in the pricing system of foreign stocks.

"We have solved the problem by revising the program so that it will avoid calculating the price of foreign stocks, which is what caused the failure," Tokyo bourse president Mitsuhide Yamaguchi said in a statement.
"Concerning the matter of calculating share prices, we will conduct a review, including one on the program itself," he added.
On Friday, the trading system was out of action for the entire two-hour morning session, halting trade in more than 1,700 issues, 108 of them on the benchmark Nikkei 225 average.
Unlike in October 1990, when a problem with cables halted trade, on Friday the electronic trading system itself crashed, the first time that has happened.
It was the worst mishap since the system was introduced in 1982, the bourse said.
"We regret that we caused much disturbance," Yamaguchi said.
